hero.title: Why and how we breed
hero.subtitle: Breeding is not just about producing more rats. It is about shaping healthy, stable companions while respecting their welfare.

sections.title: Four pillars of Ratopia
sections.subtitle: These principles guide every pairing decision and every adoption.

items.title: Temperament comes first
items.text: We keep and breed rats that are curious, people-oriented and recover quickly from stress. We do not keep rats with chronic fear or aggression, even if they look rare or pretty.

items.title: Health and longevity
items.text: We track family health histories, remove problematic branches, and avoid repeating pairings that show patterns of early illness, tumors or severe respiratory issues.

items.title: Ethical scale
items.text: We keep numbers small so that every rat is known as an individual. No back-to-back litters, no breeding to fill orders, and no pairing just for color experiments.

items.title: Honesty and transparency
items.text: We share what we know, but also what we do not know yet. Lines in development will be clearly labeled, and adopters are told about both strengths and weaknesses.

body.text: Before planning a litter, we look at the temperament, health, structure and background of both parents. We are not chasing a single trait, but looking at the overall picture.

If a rat has a wonderful temperament but a weaker health history, they may still be loved as a pet and not used in breeding. Likewise, a healthy animal that hates handling will not be used, even if their genotype is interesting.

items: No breeding rats with severe chronic issues.
No breeding purely "because they are pretty".

sections.title: Adoption and placement
sections.subtitle: Finding the right homes matters just as much as breeding the right rats.

body.text: We prefer adopters who are willing to learn, ask questions and adjust husbandry when presented with new information. Perfect cages and setups are not required, but openness and responsibility are.

items: Rats should be kept with compatible companions, not alone.
Adequate space, ventilation and enrichment are non-negotiable.
Adopters should be prepared for veterinary care and ageing.

body.text: If an adopter's situation changes, we would always rather be contacted early than have rats silently neglected or abandoned.
